comments.text: This is an incredible guide! I already knew a lot of things you talked about here, but I still managed to learn some new things too! I'll be sure to come back to this video for future reference!

comments.text: Thanks for teaching us how to be light pros. Appreciated the bit about the SAD lamps. As someone who has a hard time in winter that was helpful. We had one when I was in high school, and I’m a very literal person. People said it was supposed to help me by “looking at it,” so while it was sitting on the desk by our computer I would be staring right at it. 😅 I do not reccomend looking right at it. Haha
comments.author: @mareep_the_sheep

comments.text: I've seen many videos on design principles. Lui, yours are exceptional - clear, well organized, comprehensive, and appealing to the viewer's intelligence. Great job. One question re this video: you said 3500-4000 is neutral light,  2700-3000 K is warm - leaving 3000-3500 unaddressed. Did you mean to say that warm is 2700-3500?
comments.author: @kenberian4863

comments.text:
Opa, vídeo ótimo como sempre! I'd like to ask you something on lighting:
What are your comments on textured/geometric light/shadow lamps? those that produces a light with shape, not only color (think of the effect that water ripple have on light, or a caleidoscopic-holed lampshade). What type of bulb should I use with these and how can I use them to compose a good ambiance?

Se tiver alguma recomendação mais específica de abajur/luminária com esse efeito disponível aqui no Brasil, n deixa de colocar no teu link!

comments.text:
Hi Lui light pro here & really helpful and inspirational video
I think all stairs should be lit 
I like those tubes that give extra light on bookshelves etc
I saw some young lads light up their Italian mansion’s garden and it was really beautiful as it highlighted the architecture of the building but also their garden and statues.
comments.author: @KymTugwell

comments.text:
I love playing with light.  I start by using natural light sources to determine my room's layout, then add in the ambient and task lights. The accent and decorative lights are where I have the most fun. My favorites these days are spotlights with goboes (a patterned stencil on the light source that creates interesting shadows) on a plant-filled corner to create a sense of movement and forest shadows, and small, low-wattage stained glass table lamps to serve as a way-finding light in a darkened room or hallway. The patterned shadows and dappled color washes add depth and texture in the evening hours.

You may want to expand your light curriculum to include the versatility that certain technical components offer:  dimmer switches, "smart" fixtures, motion and dawn-to-dusk sensing fixtures. And if you're into landscape lighting, the world opens to include solar fixtures. I've been having a lot of fun in this category, as well, experimenting with renter-friendly ways to light a deck and shadowy exterior walkways/staircases instead of relying on harsh, high-powered floodlights.
comments.author: @kimsnader8777

comments.text: Great!
comments.author: @annacalhan2628

comments.text: I've seen many videos on design principles. Lui, yours are exceptional - clear, well organized, comprehensive, and appealing to the viewer's intelligence. Great job. One question re this video: you said 3500-4000 is neutral light,  2700-3000 K is warm - leaving 3000-3500 unaddressed. Did you mean to say that warm is 2700-3500?
comments.author: @kenberian4863

comments.text: Thanks for teaching us how to be light pros. Appreciated the bit about the SAD lamps. As someone who has a hard time in winter that was helpful. We had one when I was in high school, and I’m a very literal person. People said it was supposed to help me by “looking at it,” so while it was sitting on the desk by our computer I would be staring right at it. 😅 I do not reccomend looking right at it. Haha
comments.author: @mareep_the_sheep

comments.text:
Really pro lights needs a full video about the latest in programmable hue lighting. I'm designing for a household with several sleep disorders and at least one night shift worker, and I need to be able to program the light hue to support people waking up comfortably in the morning, being fully awake, alert, and productive in the middle of the day, and being able to calm down and go to sleep at a sensible time at night - including the night shift suite being programmed on a different time zone to the rest of the house. Also I absolutely will not have our household lighting or any other household management systems connected to the internet or depending on an app to work. We need wired-in controls and a household systems computer that is not connected to the internet.

The almighty al-thingy hasn't offered me any updates on this technology in a while, and I'd really like to know what the latest offerings are from the various manufacturers in this space.
comments.author: @tealkerberus748

comments.text:
Opa, vídeo ótimo como sempre! I'd like to ask you something on lighting:
What are your comments on textured/geometric light/shadow lamps? those that produces a light with shape, not only color (think of the effect that water ripple have on light, or a caleidoscopic-holed lampshade). What type of bulb should I use with these and how can I use them to compose a good ambiance?

comments.author: @Pedro-k2q5h

comments.text:
Regarding human circadian rhythm when it gets fully dark outside it is much better to minimise blue spectrum light inside our homes.

You can only do that effectively by using either old style very warm temperature Incandescent bulbs. Or by using specialist zero blue spectrum 1800K temperature LED bulbs.

You can take it even further if you have one of the latest high end smartphones that have a eye comfort night mode zero blue spectrum filter.
comments.author: @C--A

comments.text: Light Pro. My favorite episode so far. I love lighting theory and design! A great lighting plan really makes or breaks a space.

comments.text: Thanks for teaching us how to be light pros. Appreciated the bit about the SAD lamps. As someone who has a hard time in winter that was helpful. comments.author: @KymTugwell

comments.text:
I love playing with light.  I start by using natural light sources to determine my room's layout, then add in the ambient and task lights. The accent and decorative lights are where I have the most fun. My favorites these days are spotlights with goboes (a patterned stencil on the light source that creates interesting shadows) on a plant-filled corner to create a sense of movement and forest shadows, and small, low-wattage stained glass table lamps to serve as a way-finding light in a darkened room or hallway. The patterned shadows and dappled color washes add depth and texture in the evening hours.

You may want to expand your light curriculum to include the versatility that certain technical components offer:  dimmer switches, "smart" fixtures, motion and dawn-to-dusk sensing fixtures. And if you're into landscape lighting, the world opens to include solar fixtures. I've been having a lot of fun in this category, as well, experimenting with renter-friendly ways to light a deck and shadowy exterior walkways/staircases instead of relying on harsh, high-powered floodlights.
comments.author: @kimsnader8777

comments.text: I've seen many videos on design principles. Lui, yours are exceptional - clear, well organized, comprehensive, and appealing to the viewer's intelligence. Great job. One question re this video: you said 3500-4000 is neutral light,  2700-3000 K is warm - leaving 3000-3500 unaddressed. Did you mean to say that warm is 2700-3500?
comments.author: @kenberian4863

comments.text:
Regarding human circadian rhythm when it gets fully dark outside it is much better to minimise blue spectrum light inside our homes.

You can only do that effectively by using either old style very warm temperature Incandescent bulbs. Or by using specialist zero blue spectrum 1800K temperature LED bulbs.

You can take it even further if you have one of the latest high end smartphones that have a eye comfort night mode zero blue spectrum filter.
comments.author: @C--A

comments.text:
Really pro lights needs a full video about the latest in programmable hue lighting. I'm designing for a household with several sleep disorders and at least one night shift worker, and I need to be able to program the light hue to support people waking up comfortably in the morning, being fully awake, alert, and productive in the middle of the day, and being able to calm down and go to sleep at a sensible time at night - including the night shift suite being programmed on a different time zone to the rest of the house. Also I absolutely will not have our household lighting or any other household management systems connected to the internet or depending on an app to work. We need wired-in controls and a household systems computer that is not connected to the internet.

The almighty al-thingy hasn't offered me any updates on this technology in a while, and I'd really like to know what the latest offerings are from the various manufacturers in this space.
comments.author: @tealkerberus748

comments.text:
Opa, vídeo ótimo como sempre! I'd like to ask you something on lighting:
What are your comments on textured/geometric light/shadow lamps? those that produces a light with shape, not only color (think of the effect that water ripple have on light, or a caleidoscopic-holed lampshade). What type of bulb should I use with these and how can I use them to compose a good ambiance?
